title: Parts of Speech
description: Learn the building blocks of sentences: nouns, verbs, adjectives, and more.

children.title: Common and Proper Nouns
children.contentHTML:
Definition

Nouns are words used to name people, things, or ideas. They can function as subjects or objects in a sentence.

  • Common Nouns: Refer to general groups of people, things, or phenomena. (e.g., a camera, a river, a city)
  • Proper Nouns: Refer to the specific name of a person, place, or thing. Proper nouns must always be capitalized. (e.g., Canon, Paris, John)

children.title: Concrete and Abstract Nouns
children.contentHTML:
• Concrete Nouns: Refer to a person, place, or thing that is tangible and can be perceived through the senses (sight, sound, touch, taste, smell).
    Example: Tom just gave me some apples.
  • Abstract Nouns: Refer to concepts, ideas, or phenomena that are intangible and cannot be perceived by the senses.
    Example: Jane's childhood memory has always been her fear.

children.title: Countable and Uncountable Nouns
children.contentHTML:
• Countable Nouns: Refer to people, things, etc., that can be counted and expressed with a specific number. They have singular and plural forms.
    Examples: one book (singular), two books (plural); a man, many men.
  • Uncountable Nouns: Refer to things or concepts that cannot be counted with specific numbers. They do not have a plural form.
    Examples: water, food, information, sand, hope.

children.title: Compound Nouns
children.contentHTML:
A compound noun is formed by combining two or more separate words to create a new noun. They can be categorized into three types:

  • Open/Spaced: Words are separate. (e.g., bus stop, ice cream)
  • Hyphenated: Words are joined by a hyphen. (e.g., mother-in-law, warm-up)
  • Closed/Solid: Words are merged into one. (e.g., haircut, police officer)

children.title: Personal Pronouns
children.contentHTML:
Personal pronouns replace nouns referring to specific people or things to avoid repetition. They have two forms based on their role in a sentence.

Subject PronounsObject Pronouns
Ime
Youyou
Theythem
Weus
Hehim
Sheher
Itit

Example: My mother is a good doctor. She has done many successful surgeries.

children.title: Possessive Pronouns
children.contentHTML:
Possessive pronouns indicate ownership and replace a noun phrase (e.g., 'my book' becomes 'mine').

  • mine: Her dress is black, mine is pink.
  • yours: I've got my pen. Where is yours?
  • ours: That house is ours.
  • hers: He got his certificate a year ago, but she just got hers.
  • his: My car is white; his is blue.
  • theirs: My notebook looks the same as theirs.
  • its: The cat has a toy. The ball is its.

children.title: Relative Pronouns
children.contentHTML:
Relative pronouns connect a clause or phrase to a noun or pronoun. They introduce a relative clause, which provides more information about the noun.

  • who: Refers to people. (The woman who called you is my boss.)
  • whom: Refers to people (as an object). (The girl whom I met is my best friend.)
  • which: Refers to things. (This is the comic which he bought 3 years ago.)
  • whose: Refers to possession for people or things. (The woman whose name is Lona is my teacher.)
  • that: Refers to people or things. (This is the book that belongs to Jane.)

children.title: Interrogative Pronouns
children.contentHTML:
Interrogative pronouns are used to ask questions. The answer to the question is typically a noun or noun phrase. They usually appear at the beginning of a question.

  • What: What did he do in Japan?
  • Which: Which sport does she like better, badminton or basketball?
  • Who: Who is at the door?
  • Whom: Whom did you invite to the party?
  • Whose: Whose jacket is this?

children.title: Possessive Adjectives
children.contentHTML:
Possessive adjectives are used to show ownership or possession. They come before a noun. They are different from possessive pronouns.

Personal PronounPossessive Adjective
Imy
Youyour
Weour
Theytheir
Hehis
Sheher
Itits

Example: That is her book. (The book belongs to her).

children.title: -ing and -ed Adjectives
children.contentHTML:
These adjectives are formed from verbs but describe nouns.

  • -ing Adjectives: Describe the quality or characteristic of a person, thing, or situation that causes a feeling. They describe the source.
    Example: This old game is boring. (The game causes boredom.)
  • -ed Adjectives: Describe a person's feeling or emotion as a result of something. They describe the effect.
    Example: I am bored because this game is boring. (I feel boredom.)

children.title: Order of Adjectives
children.contentHTML:
When multiple adjectives are used before a noun, they usually follow a specific order in English. This helps sentences sound natural.

The typical order is:

  1. Quantity or number (e.g., two, several)
  2. Opinion (e.g., beautiful, boring)
  3. Size (e.g., big, small)
  4. Age (e.g., young, old)
  5. Shape (e.g., round, square)
  6. Color (e.g., red, blue)
  7. Origin (e.g., Japanese, American)
  8. Material (e.g., wooden, metal)
  9. Purpose (e.g., sleeping [as in "sleeping bag"])

Example: A beautiful small old round red Italian wooden jewelry box.

Note: Native speakers sometimes bend the rules, but this is the standard order.

children.title: Action Verbs
children.contentHTML:
Action verbs express a physical or mental action. They describe what the subject of the sentence is doing.

  • Physical Actions: run, jump, crash, cook
  • Mental Actions: think, miss, learn, believe

children.title: Irregular Verbs
children.contentHTML:
Irregular verbs do not follow the standard rule of adding '-ed' to form the past simple and past participle forms. You must memorize them.

Base FormPast SimplePast Participle
beginbeganbegun
bringbroughtbrought
eatateeaten

children.title: Modal Verbs
children.contentHTML:
Modal verbs are auxiliary (helping) verbs that express ability, possibility, permission, or obligation. The main verb that follows a modal is always in its base form.

  • Can / Could / Be able to (Ability): Jane can play badminton.
  • Must / Have to (Obligation): He must be tired.
  • May / Might (Possibility): It may be cold.
  • Will / Would / Shall (Future/Intention): John will win this game.
  • Should / Ought to (Advice): You should lock the doors.

children.title: Verb 'to be'
children.contentHTML:
The verb 'to be' (am, is, are, was, were) can act as a main verb to describe a state or characteristic, or as an auxiliary verb in continuous tenses and the passive voice.

  • As a Main Verb: Jane is very beautiful.
  • As an Auxiliary Verb: This beautiful house was built in 2000.

children.title: Auxiliary Verbs (Helping Verbs)
children.contentHTML:
Auxiliary verbs (like 'be', 'do', 'have') help the main verb to show tense, mood, or voice. They are used to form questions, negative sentences, and complex tenses.

  • 'do' for negatives/questions: Henry does his housework well. He does not like it.
  • 'have' for perfect tenses: I have finished my work.

children.title: Phrasal Verbs
children.contentHTML:
A phrasal verb is a combination of a verb and a preposition or adverb, creating a meaning different from the original verb.

Example: Don't bank on Henry to do that. ('Bank on' means 'to rely on').

children.title: Transitive and Intransitive Verbs
children.contentHTML:
• Intransitive Verbs: Express an action that does not have a direct object. The action is complete on its own.
    Example: She agreed. The sun rises.
  • Transitive Verbs: Express an action that has a direct object. The verb 'transfers' its action to something or someone.
    Example: He owed Jane a lot of money. (The object is 'Jane').

children.title: Linking Verbs
children.contentHTML:
Linking verbs connect the subject of a sentence to a subject complement (a noun or adjective that describes the subject). They don't show action; they show a state of being.

Common linking verbs: be, feel, look, sound, smell, taste, seem, become, appear, remain.

Example: Jane seems happy. The biscuit tastes sweet.

children.title: Adverbs of Place
children.contentHTML:
Adverbs of place describe where an action happens. They answer the question 'Where?'.

Common examples: here, there, somewhere, inside, outside, downstairs, between.

Example: Jane is cooking downstairs.

children.title: Adverbs of Degree
children.contentHTML:
Adverbs of degree describe the intensity or extent of an action, adjective, or another adverb. They answer the question 'To what extent?'.

Common examples: hardly, little, fully, very, extremely, quite.

Example: I need hardly say that I was very happy.

children.title: Adverbs of Time
children.contentHTML:
Adverbs of time describe when an action happens. They answer the question 'When?'.

Common examples: early, now, soon, finally, last year, yesterday, today.

Example: I went to Dubai with my family last year.

children.title: Adverbs of Manner
children.contentHTML:
Adverbs of manner describe how an action happens. They answer the question 'How?'. Many end in '-ly'.

Common examples: noisily, unfortunately, carefully, slowly, happily.

Example: My sister is chewing the food noisily.

children.title: Adverbs of Frequency
children.contentHTML:
Adverbs of frequency describe how often an action happens. They answer the question 'How often?'.

Common examples: always, usually, sometimes, rarely, never.

Example: Jane always goes to school on time.

children.title: Few, a few, little, a little
children.contentHTML:
• A few / Few: Used with plural countable nouns.
    • A few: A small number (positive, 'some'). (I have a few friends.)
    • Few: Not many (negative, 'almost none'). (Few people came to the party.)
  • A little / Little: Used with uncountable nouns.
    • A little: A small amount (positive, 'some'). (I have a little money.)
    • Little: Not much (negative, 'almost none'). (There is little hope.)

children.title: Some and Any
children.contentHTML:
Both are used with plural countable nouns and uncountable nouns.

  • Some: Used in positive/affirmative sentences and in offers/requests.
    Example: Henry bought some pencils. Would you like some tea?
  • Any: Used in negative sentences and most questions.
    Example: There aren't any tomatoes in the kitchen. Do you have any questions?

children.title: Much and Many
children.contentHTML:
Both mean 'a large amount/number' and are often used in questions and negative sentences. 'A lot of' is more common in positive sentences.

  • Many: Used with plural countable nouns.
    Example: Many of my friends like playing badminton.
  • Much: Used with uncountable nouns.
    Example: How much time does she have left?

children.title: Prepositions of Place
children.contentHTML:
These prepositions clarify information about a location or position.

Common examples: in, on, at, under, between, behind, in front of.

Example: Jane is in her room. The cat is on the table.

children.title: Prepositions of Time
children.contentHTML:
These prepositions clarify information about the time an event occurs.

  • On: For days and dates. (on Monday, on May 5th)
  • At: For specific times and certain points in the day. (at 9 p.m., at noon)
  • In: For longer periods like months, years, seasons, and parts of the day. (in the evening, in 2023, in summer)

children.title: Other Prepositions
children.contentHTML:
• Direction/Movement: to, from, up, down, across, along
  • Agent/Instrument: by, with, on
  • Reason/Purpose: for, because of, from, through

children.title: Definite and Indefinite Articles
children.contentHTML:
Articles are words that come before a noun to specify whether the noun is general or specific.

  • The (Definite Article): Used to refer to a specific, unique, or previously mentioned noun that both the speaker and listener know.
    Example: Can you pass me the salt? (The specific salt on the table).
  • A / An (Indefinite Article): Used to refer to a general or non-specific noun. 'A' is used before consonant sounds, and 'An' is used before vowel sounds.
    Example: I need to buy a car. I saw an elephant.

children.title: Coordinating Conjunctions
children.contentHTML:
Coordinating conjunctions connect words, phrases, or independent clauses of equal grammatical rank. You can remember them with the acronym FANBOYS.

  • For - (presents a reason)
  • And - (adds information)
  • Nor - (presents a negative alternative)
  • But - (shows contrast)
  • Or - (presents a choice)
  • Yet - (shows contrast, similar to but)
  • So - (presents a result)

Example: I want to play badminton and handball.

children.title: Subordinating Conjunctions
children.contentHTML:
Subordinating conjunctions connect an independent clause (a complete thought) with a dependent clause (an incomplete thought). The dependent clause cannot stand alone as a sentence.

Common examples: because, since, as, although, before, after, while, if, unless.

Example: Although Henry had a broken leg, he still passed the final exam.

children.title: Correlative Conjunctions
children.contentHTML:
Correlative conjunctions work in pairs to join grammatically equal elements in a sentence.

  • either ... or: You can have either tea or coffee.
  • neither ... nor: He is neither a teacher nor a student.
  • both ... and: She likes both cats and dogs.
  • not only ... but also: We play badminton not only on Tuesday but also on Sunday.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which of the following is a proper noun and should be capitalized?
grammarQuestions.explanation: Proper nouns name specific places, people, or things. 'Spain' is the specific name of a country.

grammarQuestions.prompt: My favorite writer is ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The specific name of a person is a proper noun and must be capitalized.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Select all the abstract nouns from the list.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Abstract nouns like 'happiness' and 'courage' are ideas or concepts that you cannot perceive with your five senses.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which noun in the sentence 'Her bravery was admired by everyone' is an abstract noun?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Bravery' is a quality or idea, making it an abstract noun. You cannot see or touch it.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which of these are uncountable nouns?
grammarQuestions.explanation: Uncountable nouns, like 'advice' and 'information', cannot be counted with numbers and do not have a plural form.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I need to buy two ___ of bread.
grammarQuestions.explanation: While 'bread' is uncountable, we use counters like 'loaves' to count it.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which of the following is a closed/solid compound noun?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Sunflower' is a closed compound noun because the two words 'sun' and 'flower' are joined together without a space or hyphen.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Let's meet at the ___ stop.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Bus stop' is an open compound noun, where 'bus' modifies 'stop'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: John is a doctor. ___ works at the city hospital.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'He' is a subject pronoun used to replace 'John' as the one performing the action.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The teacher gave the books to ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use an object pronoun (like 'us') because it is receiving the action of the verb 'gave'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: That blue car is not yours, it's ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Mine' is a possessive pronoun that replaces 'my car' to show ownership.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I have finished my homework. Have you finished ___?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Yours' is a possessive pronoun that replaces 'your homework'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The woman ___ lives next door is a famous musician.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the relative pronoun 'who' to refer to people.

grammarQuestions.prompt: This is the book ___ I was telling you about.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'that' or 'which' as a relative pronoun to refer to things.

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ of these two dresses do you prefer?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Which' is used as an interrogative pronoun to ask about a choice between a limited number of options.

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ is responsible for this project?
grammarQuestions.explanation: The interrogative pronoun 'Who' is used to ask questions about a person.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I can't find ___ keys.
grammarQuestions.explanation: A possessive adjective like 'my' must come before a noun ('keys') to show ownership.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The dog wagged ___ tail happily.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Its' is the possessive adjective for 'it'. Do not confuse it with 'it's' (it is).

grammarQuestions.prompt: I was very ___ after the long hike.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the '-ed' adjective ('tired') to describe your own feeling. The hike was 'tiring'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The news was quite ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the '-ing' adjective ('shocking') to describe the quality of the news (the source of the feeling).

grammarQuestions.prompt: Choose the correct order of adjectives.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The standard order of adjectives is Opinion -> Age -> Color -> Material. 'new' (age), 'black' (color), 'leather' (material).

grammarQuestions.prompt: She bought a ___ ___ car.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Adjectives of opinion ('beautiful', 'big') usually come before adjectives of color ('red', 'blue').

grammarQuestions.prompt: Select all the action verbs.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Run' (physical) and 'think' (mental) describe actions. 'Is' and 'seems' are linking verbs.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Yesterday, I ___ a delicious cake.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The past simple of the irregular verb 'eat' is 'ate'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: They have ___ a new house.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The past participle of the irregular verb 'buy' is 'bought'. It is used here with 'have' to form the present perfect tense.

grammarQuestions.prompt: You ___ finish your homework before you go out.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Must' is a modal verb used to express a strong obligation.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She ___ play the piano beautifully.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The modal verb 'can' is used to express ability.

grammarQuestions.prompt: They ___ not at home last night.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'were' for the past tense of 'to be' with the pronoun 'they'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ you see the movie last night?
grammarQuestions.explanation: The auxiliary verb 'do' (in its past form 'did') is used to form questions in the past simple tense.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Please ___ your shoes before entering the house.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'take off' means to remove clothing or shoes.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which sentence contains an intransitive verb?
grammarQuestions.explanation: The verb 'fly' is intransitive here because it does not have a direct object. The action is complete by itself.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The flowers ___ beautiful.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Linking verbs like 'look', 'smell', or 'are' connect the subject ('flowers') to an adjective ('beautiful') that describes it.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The children are playing ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Outside' is an adverb of place because it answers the question 'Where?'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: It is ___ cold today.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Adverbs of degree like 'very' modify the adjective 'cold' to describe its intensity.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I will call you ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Later' is an adverb of time because it answers the question 'When?'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He drives his car very ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Adverbs of manner like 'carefully' describe how the action ('drives') is performed.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She ___ eats breakfast.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Always' is an adverb of frequency because it answers the question 'How often?'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Select all the adverbs of manner.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Quickly' and 'softly' describe how an action is done. 'Often' is frequency, and 'here' is place.

grammarQuestions.prompt: There's ___ milk left in the fridge, just enough for one coffee.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'a little' with uncountable nouns ('milk') to mean a small, but positive, amount.

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ people understand his theories. He feels very isolated.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'few' with countable nouns ('people') to mean 'not many', with a negative connotation.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Do you have ___ questions?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Any' is typically used in questions and negative sentences.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I would like ___ water, please.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Some' is used in positive statements and in offers or requests.

grammarQuestions.prompt: How ___ sugar do you want in your tea?
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'much' with uncountable nouns ('sugar') in questions.

grammarQuestions.prompt: There aren't ___ students in the library today.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'many' with countable nouns ('students') in negative sentences.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The keys are ___ the table.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the preposition 'on' to indicate that something is on a surface.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She lives ___ London.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the preposition 'in' for cities, countries, and other large areas.

grammarQuestions.prompt: My birthday is ___ June.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the preposition 'in' for months, years, and seasons.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The meeting starts ___ 3 p.m.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the preposition 'at' for specific times.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She is ___ amazing artist.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'an' before a word that starts with a vowel sound ('amazing').

grammarQuestions.prompt: Could you please close ___ door?
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'the' because you are referring to a specific door that both people in the conversation know about.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I wanted to go to the beach, ___ it was raining.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The conjunction 'but' is used to show a contrast between two ideas.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He was tired, ___ he went to bed early.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The conjunction 'so' is used to show a result or consequence.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I will wait here ___ you get back.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Until' is a subordinating conjunction that connects an action to a point in time.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She passed the exam ___ she studied hard.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The subordinating conjunction 'because' is used to give a reason.

grammarQuestions.prompt: You can have ___ tea ___ coffee.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The correlative conjunction 'either...or' is used to present two choices.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He is ___ rich, but he is also humble.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The correlative conjunction 'not only...but also' is used to add an extra, often surprising, piece of information.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which of these words are common nouns?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'River' and 'car' are general categories (common nouns), while 'Amazon' and 'Toyota' are specific names (proper nouns).

grammarQuestions.prompt: Is 'music' a concrete or abstract noun?
grammarQuestions.explanation: While you can hear music (perceive its effect), the concept of 'music' itself is an idea, making it an abstract noun.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Could I have a piece of ___?
grammarQuestions.explanation: Uncountable nouns like 'advice' and 'information' often use 'a piece of' to be quantified.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which type of compound noun is 'ice cream'?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Ice cream' is an open compound noun because it is written as two separate words.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which of the following are object pronouns?
grammarQuestions.explanation: Object pronouns ('them', 'her') receive the action of a verb. Subject pronouns ('I', 'we') perform the action.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The dog has its toy. The toy is ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The possessive pronoun for 'it' is 'its'. It shows ownership and stands alone.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The boy ___ bike was stolen went to the police.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the relative pronoun 'whose' to show possession (the bike belongs to the boy).

grammarQuestions.prompt: To ___ should I address this letter?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Whom' is the correct interrogative pronoun to use when asking about the object of a verb or preposition ('to').

grammarQuestions.prompt: The team celebrated ___ victory.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Their' is a possessive adjective that must be followed by a noun ('victory').

grammarQuestions.prompt: It's so ___ when people talk during a movie.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the '-ing' adjective to describe the thing or situation that causes the feeling (the source).

grammarQuestions.prompt: He wore a ___ ___ ___ shirt.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The order is generally size/opinion, then age, then material. For example: size (big), age (old), material (cotton).

grammarQuestions.prompt: The sun has ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Risen' is the past participle of the irregular verb 'rise', used with 'has' in the present perfect tense.

grammarQuestions.prompt: It ___ rain later, so bring an umbrella.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The modal verbs 'might' or 'may' are used to express possibility.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She ___ not like spicy food.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The auxiliary verb 'do' (in its third-person form 'does') is used to form negative sentences in the present simple.

grammarQuestions.prompt: We need to ___ a solution to this problem.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'come up with' means to think of or create something, like a plan or solution.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which sentence contains a transitive verb?
grammarQuestions.explanation: The verb 'wrote' is transitive because it has a direct object ('a letter') that receives the action.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Select all the sentences that contain a linking verb.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Tastes' and 'seems' are linking verbs because they connect the subject to a word that describes it. 'Ran' and 'built' are action verbs.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I ___ go to the gym, maybe once or twice a month.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Adverbs of frequency like 'rarely' or 'seldom' indicate that an action does not happen often.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He has ___ patience for long meetings.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'little' with the uncountable noun 'patience' to mean 'not much', with a negative sense.

grammarQuestions.prompt: There isn't ___ sugar left.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Any' is used with uncountable nouns in negative sentences.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She has so ___ friends.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'many' with the plural countable noun 'friends'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: We always have a big family dinner ___ Christmas Day.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the preposition 'on' for specific days and dates.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The office is ___ the third floor.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'on' to talk about floors in a building.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He is studying to be ___ engineer.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'an' before 'engineer' because it starts with a vowel sound.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I saw a movie last night. ___ movie was very good.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'the' to refer to the movie that has already been mentioned.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which sentences use a coordinating conjunction correctly?

options.text: She is smart, and she is kind.
He didn't study, so he failed the test.
I will go but it rains.

grammarQuestions.explanation: 'And' adds information, and 'so' shows a result. Both connect two independent clauses correctly.

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ he is very rich, he is not happy.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Although' is a subordinating conjunction used to show contrast or concession.

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ my mother ___ my father can speak French.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The correlative conjunction 'neither...nor' is used to connect two negative alternatives.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which word is the common noun in the sentence: 'The girl threw the ball to her dog, Fido'?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Girl' is a general person (common noun), while 'Fido' is a specific name (proper noun).

grammarQuestions.prompt: His great ___ is his main quality.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Abstract nouns like 'strength', 'honesty', or 'kindness' name qualities you cannot touch.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Can you give me ___ water?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Water' is an uncountable noun. We use 'some' to talk about an unspecified amount of it.

grammarQuestions.prompt: My ___ is a doctor.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Brother-in-law' is an example of a hyphenated compound noun.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Mary and I are going to the cinema. ___ are very excited.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the subject pronoun 'We' to replace 'Mary and I'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Our house is big, but ___ is bigger.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Theirs' is a possessive pronoun that replaces 'their house'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The reason ___ I am late is that my car broke down.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The relative pronoun 'why' is often used after 'the reason'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ do you think will win the game?
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'Who' to ask about the person who is the subject of the verb 'win'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Look at that cat and ___ kittens.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The possessive adjective 'its' is used to show that the kittens belong to the cat.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Select the sentence where the adjective is used correctly.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use '-ed' for feelings ('I am interested') and '-ing' for the source of the feeling ('History is interesting').

grammarQuestions.prompt: He has a ___ knife.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The typical order is Size (small) -> Quality/Opinion (sharp) -> Material (metal).

grammarQuestions.prompt: I have already ___ that movie.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Seen' is the past participle of the irregular verb 'see', used with 'have' to form the present perfect.

grammarQuestions.prompt: You ___ be joking! That's impossible.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Must' can be used here to express a strong assumption or logical conclusion.

grammarQuestions.prompt: This book ___ written by a famous author.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The verb 'to be' ('was') is used as an auxiliary verb to form the passive voice.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Don't ___. You can do it!
grammarQuestions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'give up' means to quit or stop trying.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He ___ tired after a long day at work.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Felt' is a linking verb that connects the subject 'He' to the adjective 'tired'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Please put the books back ___ on the shelf.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'There' is an adverb of place indicating a specific location away from the speaker.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I ___ agree with your opinion.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Completely' is an adverb of degree that describes the extent to which you agree.

grammarQuestions.prompt: We moved to this city two years ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Ago' is an adverb of time used to indicate a point in the past measured from the present.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She speaks English ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: An adverb of manner ('fluently') is needed to describe how she speaks. 'Fluent' is an adjective.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He is ___ late for meetings.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Adverbs of frequency like 'never' are usually placed after the verb 'to be'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I have ___ friends, so I'm never lonely.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'a few' with countable nouns ('friends') to mean 'a small number' in a positive sense.

grammarQuestions.prompt: We don't have ___ bread left.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Any' is used in negative sentences with both countable and uncountable nouns.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The picture is hanging ___ the wall.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'on' to describe something attached to a vertical surface like a wall.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The shop is closed ___ Sundays.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the preposition 'on' for days of the week.

grammarQuestions.prompt: It takes me ___ hour to get to work.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'an' because 'hour' starts with a silent 'h', so its first sound is a vowel sound.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Would you like tea ___ coffee?
grammarQuestions.explanation: The conjunction 'or' is used to present a choice or alternative.

grammarQuestions.prompt: You can't go out ___ you finish your homework.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Unless' is a subordinating conjunction meaning 'except if'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She is good at ___ math ___ science.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The correlative conjunction 'both...and' is used to connect two things that are both true.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which of these are abstract nouns?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Love' and 'friendship' are concepts or ideas that cannot be physically touched, making them abstract nouns.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He gave me a lot of good ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Advice' is an uncountable noun and does not have a plural form.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Can you help ___ with this heavy box?
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the object pronoun 'me' because it is receiving the action 'help'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: That's the hospital ___ I was born.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The relative adverb 'where' is used to give more information about a place ('hospital').

grammarQuestions.prompt: I find his lectures very ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use an '-ing' adjective to describe the quality of the lectures (the source of the feeling).

grammarQuestions.prompt: He ___ the answer to the question immediately.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The past simple of the irregular verb 'know' is 'knew'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ you mind opening the window?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Would you mind...' is a polite way to ask someone to do something.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I need to ___ my keys. I can't find them anywhere.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'look for' means to search for something.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The sun was ___ brightly.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Shining' is used here as an intransitive verb; it does not need a direct object to make sense.

grammarQuestions.prompt: This test was ___ easy.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Adverbs of degree like 'extremely' describe the intensity of an adjective ('easy').

grammarQuestions.prompt: I don't have ___ time to finish this.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'much' with the uncountable noun 'time' in negative sentences.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The letter was written ___ a blue pen.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'with' to talk about the instrument or tool used to do something.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I will see you ___ the morning.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the preposition 'in' for parts of the day like 'in the morning', 'in the afternoon', 'in the evening'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ Pacific Ocean is the largest ocean in the world.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the definite article 'the' before names of oceans, seas, and rivers.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I have to work late, ___ I can't join you for dinner.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'So' is a coordinating conjunction used to indicate a result or consequence.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Please call me ___ you arrive.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'When' is a subordinating conjunction that introduces a time clause.

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ you apologize, ___ will I.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Neither...nor' is used to present two negative facts together.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Select all the hyphenated compound nouns.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Check-in' and 'son-in-law' are examples of compound nouns where the words are joined by a hyphen.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Please pass the salt to ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the object pronoun 'her' as it is the recipient of the action.

grammarQuestions.prompt: These aren't my keys. Are they ___?
grammarQuestions.explanation: The possessive pronoun 'yours' replaces the phrase 'your keys' and can stand alone.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She wore a ___ dress.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The correct order is Opinion (beautiful), Size (long), Material (silk).

grammarQuestions.prompt: The children ___ a sandcastle on the beach.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Built' is the past simple form of the irregular verb 'build'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I ___ never been to Japan.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The auxiliary verb 'have' is used with a past participle ('been') to form the present perfect tense.

grammarQuestions.prompt: After the news, he ___ very quiet.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Linking verbs like 'became' connect the subject ('he') to his state of being ('quiet').

grammarQuestions.prompt: He answered the question ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: An adverb ('correctly') is needed to describe how he answered (the verb). 'Correct' is an adjective.

grammarQuestions.prompt: We ___ go out for dinner on Fridays.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Adverbs of frequency like 'usually' describe how often an action occurs and are often placed before the main verb.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I'm going to the library ___ some books.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The preposition 'for' is used here to state the reason or purpose of going to the library.

grammarQuestions.prompt: My father is ___ honest man.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'an' before 'honest' because the 'h' is silent, so the word starts with a vowel sound.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She doesn't like apples, ___ does she like pears.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Nor' is used to introduce a second negative idea after a first one.

grammarQuestions.prompt: We need to buy new ___ for the living room.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Furniture' is an uncountable noun. It does not have a plural form, even when referring to multiple items.

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ car is parked outside?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Whose' is an interrogative pronoun used to ask about possession or ownership.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The instructions were very ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the '-ing' adjective ('confusing') to describe the instructions (the source). 'Confused' describes how a person feels.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She has ___ a beautiful song.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Written' is the past participle of the irregular verb 'write', used here with 'has'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Can you ___ the music a little? It's too loud.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'turn down' means to reduce the volume or intensity.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which of the following are adverbs of time?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Soon' and 'yesterday' answer the question 'When?'. 'Quickly' is manner, and 'everywhere' is place.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Would you like ___ more cake?
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'some' in offers, even though it's a question.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The pharmacy is ___ the bank and the supermarket.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'between' to indicate that something is in the space separating two other things.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I couldn't go to the party ___ I was sick.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Subordinating conjunctions like 'as', 'since', or 'because' can all be used to give a reason.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which sentence has a capitalization error?

options.text: I read a book by mark twain.

grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Mark Twain' is a proper noun (a specific person's name) and must be capitalized.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which noun is concrete?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Rain' is a concrete noun because you can see, feel, and hear it.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The moment ___ he walked in, everyone fell silent.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The relative adverbs 'that' or 'when' can be used to refer to a point in time ('the moment').

grammarQuestions.prompt: They finished ___ project on time.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The possessive adjective 'their' is used before the noun 'project' to show ownership.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The thief ___ the money and ran away.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Took' is the past simple of the irregular verb 'take'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: You ___ see a doctor about that cough.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The modal verb 'should' is used to give advice.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which verb is intransitive in this sentence: 'She laughed loudly at the joke'?
grammarQuestions.explanation: The verb 'laughed' is intransitive because it does not have a direct object receiving the action.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I've looked ___ but I can't find my wallet.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Everywhere' is an adverb of place indicating a search in all possible locations.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He doesn't eat ___ meat.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'much' with the uncountable noun 'meat' in negative sentences.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The concert is ___ Saturday night.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'on' for days of the week, even when combined with a part of the day like 'night'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Can you play ___ guitar?
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'the' when talking about playing a musical instrument in general.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The film was ___ long ___ boring.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Not only...but also' is used to add a second, related quality.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which nouns are countable?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Song' and 'minute' can be counted (one song, two minutes), but 'music' and 'time' are general, uncountable concepts.

grammarQuestions.prompt: My brother and his friend are here. Can you see ___?
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the object pronoun 'them' to replace 'my brother and his friend' as they are receiving the action 'see'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Maria is looking for ___ phone.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Her' is a possessive adjective used to show that the phone belongs to Maria.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I found an ___ coin.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The standard order is Opinion (interesting), Age (old), Material (metal).

grammarQuestions.prompt: He ___ the ball over the fence.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Threw' is the past simple of the irregular verb 'throw'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I can't ___ what you're saying. Can you speak up?
grammarQuestions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'make out' means to hear or understand something with difficulty.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Select the sentences that contain a linking verb.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Appears' and 'smells' link the subject to a description. 'Played' and 'drove' are action verbs.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He was ___ tired to continue working.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The adverb of degree 'too' is used to indicate an excessive amount of something, often with a negative result.

grammarQuestions.prompt: This gift is ___ you.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The preposition 'for' is used to indicate the recipient or purpose.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I'll meet you ___ the bus stop.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'at' for specific points or locations like a bus stop or an entrance.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I need to buy ___ new pair of shoes.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'a' for a general, non-specific item. It comes before the consonant sound in 'new'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He didn't want to go, ___ he agreed to help.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The conjunction 'yet' is used to show contrast, similar to 'but'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which of these is an open compound noun?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Living room' is an open compound noun because it's written as two separate words.

grammarQuestions.prompt: In which sentences can 'that' be used correctly?

options.text: The woman that called is my boss.
The book that I read was interesting.
The man that car was stolen is here.

grammarQuestions.explanation: 'That' can refer to people (like 'who') or things (like 'which'). It cannot be used for possession ('whose').

grammarQuestions.prompt: They ___ to the mountains last weekend.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Drove' is the past simple of the irregular verb 'drive'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He ___ be at home; his car is in the driveway.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'must' to express a strong deduction or certainty based on evidence.

grammarQuestions.prompt: It's important to ___ with your colleagues.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'get along' means to have a friendly relationship with someone.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The team played ___ and won the game.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Well' is the adverb that describes how the team played. 'Good' is an adjective.

grammarQuestions.prompt: There's ___ time left, we need to hurry!
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'little' with the uncountable noun 'time' to express that there is not much time, with a sense of urgency.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The Renaissance happened ___ the 14th to the 17th centuries.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'from...to...' to indicate the start and end of a period.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She wants to be ___ astronaut when she grows up.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'an' before 'astronaut' because it starts with a vowel sound.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He has been much happier ___ he changed his job.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Since' is a subordinating conjunction used here to indicate a starting point in time for a situation.

grammarQuestions.prompt: John and Sarah are my friends. I know ___ well.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Them' is the object pronoun used to refer to 'John and Sarah'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: This is her book, and that one is ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The possessive pronoun 'his' is used to show ownership and stands alone, replacing 'his book'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The long journey was ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the '-ing' adjective to describe the journey (the source). Use '-ed' to describe how the travelers felt.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Have you ever ___ on a horse?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Ridden' is the past participle of the irregular verb 'ride', used with 'have' in a question.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I ___ a student at that university five years ago.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'was' for the past tense of 'to be' with the pronoun 'I'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which of these are adverbs of frequency?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Never' and 'sometimes' answer the question 'How often?'. 'Loudly' is manner, and 'now' is time.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He traveled ___ the world by boat.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Prepositions of movement like 'around' or 'across' describe the path of travel.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She is wearing ___ uniform.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'a' because the word 'uniform' starts with a 'y' sound (a consonant sound), even though the first letter is a vowel.

grammarQuestions.prompt: We can go to the cinema, ___ we can stay home and watch a movie.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The conjunction 'or' is used to present an alternative choice.

grammarQuestions.prompt: How much ___ do you have?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Luggage' is an uncountable noun and does not have a plural form.

grammarQuestions.prompt: This is the cafe ___ we first met.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The relative adverb 'where' is used to give more information about a place.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The glass fell and ___ into many pieces.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Broke' is the past simple of the irregular verb 'break'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: You should ___ that word in a dictionary.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'look up' means to search for information in a book or database.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He was born ___ 1990.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the preposition 'in' for years.

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ the red dress ___ the blue one looks good on you.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Either...or' is used to present a choice between two options.

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ did you meet at the conference?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Whom' is the grammatically correct choice as it's the object of the verb 'meet'. However, 'Who' is commonly used in informal speech.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Select the correctly ordered adjective phrases.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The standard order is Opinion -> Size -> Age -> Origin -> Material -> Purpose. Both correct options follow this rule.

grammarQuestions.prompt: What ___ you been doing all day?
grammarQuestions.explanation: The auxiliary verb 'have' is used with 'been' and a present participle ('doing') to form the present perfect continuous tense.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The audience applauded loudly. Is the verb 'applauded' transitive or intransitive?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Applauded' is intransitive here because it does not have a direct object. The action is complete on its own.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I have ___ good news for you.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'some' in positive statements with uncountable nouns like 'news'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The storm caused a lot of ___ to the coastal towns.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Damage' in the sense of harm is an uncountable noun and does not have a plural form.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I left my sunglasses on the ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Dashboard' is a closed/solid compound noun formed from 'dash' and 'board'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Our teacher told my friend and ___ to stay after class.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the object pronoun 'me' because it is the object of the verb 'told'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Select the sentences that correctly use a possessive pronoun.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Possessive pronouns like 'theirs' and 'mine' stand alone and replace a noun phrase (e.g., 'their decision', 'my pencil').

grammarQuestions.prompt: The company, ___ headquarters are in New York, is expanding globally.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'whose' to show possession, indicating that the headquarters belong to the company.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I was ___ by his story.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the '-ed' adjective ('fascinated') to describe your own feeling. The story itself was 'fascinating'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She inherited a ___ ___ ___ painting.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The correct order is Opinion (valuable), Age (old), Origin (French).

grammarQuestions.prompt: The cost of living has ___ sharply this year.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Risen' is the past participle of 'rise', used with 'has' to form the present perfect tense.

grammarQuestions.prompt: When I was young, I ___ run a mile in under six minutes.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Could' is used to express ability in the past.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The meeting has been ___ until next Friday.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'put off' means to postpone or delay.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which sentence uses 'grow' as a linking verb?

options.text: The farmer will grow corn this year.
As we age, we grow tired more easily.

grammarQuestions.explanation: In the second sentence, 'grow' acts as a linking verb (similar to 'become'), connecting the subject 'we' to the adjective 'tired'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The music played ___ in the background.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The adverb of manner 'softly' describes how the music was playing.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He has ___ hope of winning the lottery.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'little' with the uncountable noun 'hope' to indicate a very small amount, with a negative feeling.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She is allergic ___ nuts.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The adjective 'allergic' is followed by the preposition 'to'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I'll be ready ___ a few minutes.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'in' to indicate a period of time before something happens in the future.

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ honesty is a valuable quality.
grammarQuestions.explanation: No article is needed when talking about abstract nouns like 'honesty' in a general sense.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I must go to bed now, ___ I have an early start tomorrow.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The coordinating conjunction 'for' is used to present a reason, similar to 'because'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ it was cold, he went out without a coat.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Although' or 'Even though' are subordinating conjunctions used to show a contrast.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which of these are abstract nouns?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Patience' and 'knowledge' are concepts or qualities that cannot be perceived by the senses.

grammarQuestions.prompt: There is too much ___ on the roads this morning.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Traffic' is an uncountable noun and does not have a plural form.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Between you and ___, I think this is a bad idea.
grammarQuestions.explanation: After a preposition like 'between', always use an object pronoun ('me').

grammarQuestions.prompt: The singer, ___ performance I enjoyed, will be on tour next month.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'whose' to show possession (the performance belongs to the singer).

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ did they nominate for the award?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Whom' is the correct choice as it is the object of the verb 'nominate'. (They nominated whom?).

grammarQuestions.prompt: The company has just announced ___ annual profits.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Its' is the possessive adjective used for a singular, non-human entity like a company.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He lives in a ___ cottage.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The correct order is Opinion (charming), Size (little), Material (stone).

grammarQuestions.prompt: The price of the ticket has ___ up.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Gone' is the past participle of the irregular verb 'go', used with 'has' in the present perfect.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Why ___ you listening to me?
grammarQuestions.explanation: The auxiliary verb 'to be' ('are') is needed to form the present continuous tense ('are listening').

grammarQuestions.prompt: I unexpectedly ___ an old friend at the supermarket.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'ran into' means to meet someone by chance.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Select the adverbs of degree.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Rather' and 'almost' describe the intensity or extent of something. 'Annually' is frequency, and 'abroad' is place.

grammarQuestions.prompt: If you need ___ help, just ask.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Any' is often used in 'if' clauses to mean 'it doesn't matter what/which'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The cat is hiding ___ the bed.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The preposition 'under' means in a lower position than something else.

grammarQuestions.prompt: We need to finish this ___ Friday.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'by' to mean 'at the latest' or 'at some time before' a specific deadline.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I had ___ very strange dream last night.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'a' to introduce a singular, non-specific noun for the first time. It precedes the consonant sound in 'very'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Not only ___ he late, but he also forgot his wallet.
grammarQuestions.explanation: When a sentence begins with 'Not only', the subject and verb are inverted. 'Not only was he...'

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which word should be capitalized? 'I live on main street.'
grammarQuestions.explanation: Specific names of streets, like 'Main Street', are proper nouns and must be capitalized.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Can I have two ___ of coffee, please?
grammarQuestions.explanation: To count an uncountable noun like 'coffee', we use a counter word like 'cups'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: My parents are coming to visit. ___ will be here soon.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the subject pronoun 'They' to replace 'My parents'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Is this ___ book?
grammarQuestions.explanation: The possessive adjective 'your' must be used before the noun 'book'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I'm reading a very ___ book.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use the '-ing' adjective ('exciting') to describe the quality of the book (the source of the feeling).

grammarQuestions.prompt: She ___ her keys somewhere in the house.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Left' is the past simple of the irregular verb 'leave'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: ___ I borrow your pen for a moment?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'May' is a modal verb used to ask for permission politely.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The baby cried. Is the verb 'cried' transitive or intransitive?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Cried' is an intransitive verb because it does not require a direct object to complete its meaning.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I have ___ seen such a beautiful sunset.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The adverb of frequency 'never' is often used with the present perfect tense to talk about experiences.

grammarQuestions.prompt: We saw ___ birds during our hike.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'A lot of' is commonly used in positive sentences with countable nouns like 'birds'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I am responsible ___ this project.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The adjective 'responsible' is followed by the preposition 'for'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He is from ___ United Kingdom.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'the' before country names that include words like 'Kingdom', 'States', or 'Republic'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She studied hard, ___ she still didn't pass the exam.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The conjunctions 'yet' or 'but' are used to show an unexpected or contrasting result.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I'll do the dishes ___ you cook dinner.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'While' is a subordinating conjunction used to show that two actions are happening at the same time.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which of these are closed/solid compound nouns?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Football' and 'sunshine' are closed compound nouns, written as a single word.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The prize was awarded to ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: After the preposition 'to', you must use object pronouns ('him', 'her').

grammarQuestions.prompt: Their garden is beautiful, but ___ is more colorful.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The possessive pronoun 'ours' replaces the phrase 'our garden' and stands alone.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She has ___ a new dress for the party.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Chosen' is the past participle of 'choose', used here with 'has' to form the present perfect.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The car ___ of gas on the highway.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'ran out of' means to use all of something and have none left.

grammarQuestions.prompt: The milk has ___ sour.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Linking verbs like 'gone' or 'turned' can be used to describe a change of state.

grammarQuestions.prompt: She sings ___.
grammarQuestions.explanation: The adverb 'beautifully' is needed to describe the verb 'sings'. 'Beautiful' is an adjective.

grammarQuestions.prompt: I only speak ___ words of Japanese.
grammarQuestions.explanation: Use 'a few' with countable nouns ('words') to mean a small, but positive, number.
